questions.question_text:
You need to use a comma-separated value (CSV) file to import server inventory to Azure Migrate.
Which fields are mandatory for each entry in the CSV file?

choices.C: Server name, IP addresses, Disk 1 size (in GB), and CPU utilization percentage
choices.A: Server name, IP addresses, OS version, and Number of disks
choices.B: Server name, Cores, OS Name, and Memory (in MB)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct

Selected Answer: B
B. Server name, Cores, OS Name, and Memory (in MB)

Selected Answer: B
B is correct and supported by link given

Selected Answer: B
Besides that you need to migrate from FRS to DFSR to promote 2022 server to DC, you cannot raise domain or forest functional level to 2016 unless, at minimum, all your domain controllers are on 2016 OS

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/active-directory-functional-levels#windows-server-2016-functional-levels

Selected Answer: B
Server 2019 and 2022 cannot work with FRS

Selected Answer: B
answer is b! not possible

100% No
 The functional level of the forest is Windows Server 2012 R2. You can add an windows 2022 DC to a forest running windows 2012R2. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/active-directory-functional-levels

You cant add it when ur running FRS tho

Selected Answer: A
YES - raising the domain and forest functional is correct

Bing chat: Yes

Yes, raising the domain and forest functional levels is one of the prerequisites for adding the first domain controller that runs Windows Server 2022. You can raise domain and forest functional levels in Windows Server 2022 by following these steps:

Go to Start and open Administrative Tools.
Go to Active Directory Domains and Trusts.
In the left pane, right-click on Active Directory Domains and Trusts and select Raise Forest Functional Level.
You will see a list of forest functional levels that are available. Select the required functional level.
Note that when upgrading or transitioning Active Directory from Windows Server 2016 to Windows Server 2019 or Windows Server 2022, the Domain Functional Level (DFL) and Forest Functional Level (FFL) do not have to be raised1.

comments.content: Although it might be right, we do not need AI here, we need real life experience. We can ask Chatgpt ourselves without you posting it

ChatGPT:
The answer is B. No. Raising the domain and forest functional levels alone is not enough to ensure that you can add the first domain controller that runs Windows Server 2022. The domain also has to use DFS-R as the engine to replicate SYSVOL. The minimum requirement to add a Windows Server 2022 Domain Controller is a Windows Server 2008 functional level. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/524754/windows-server-2022-minimum-requirement-to-add-a-w
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/active-directory-functional-levels
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/get-started/hardware-requirements

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/dfs-replication/migrate-sysvol-to-dfsr

Domain controllers use a special shared folder named SYSVOL to replicate sign-in scripts and Group Policy object files to other domain controllers. Windows 2000 Server and Windows Server 2003 use the File Replication Service (FRS) to replicate SYSVOL. Windows Server 2008 uses the newer Distributed File System Replication (DFS Replication) service for domains that use the Windows Server 2008 domain functional level. Windows Server 2008 uses FRS for domains that run older domain functional levels.

Answer is Yes

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your network contains a single-domain Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) forest named contoso.com. The functional level of the forest is Windows Server
2012 R2. All domain controllers run Windows Server 2012 R2.
Sysvol replicates by using the File Replication Service (FRS).
You plan to replace the existing domain controllers with new domain controllers that will run Windows Server 2022.
You need to ensure that you can add the first domain controller that runs Windows Server 2022.
Solution: You raise the domain and forest functional levels.
Does this meet the goal?

HOTSPOT

You have the servers shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You plan to migrate file shares from Server1 to Server2.

You need to deploy the Storage Migration Service and the Storage Migration Service extension.

On which server should you install each component? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content: You cannot install WAC on DC..

discussion.content:
Check the Storage Migration Service requirements and install the latest version of Windows Admin Center on your PC or a management server if you haven't already. You also need the latest version of the Storage Migration Service extension, which is installed automatically by Windows Admin Center if Automatically update extensions is enabled in Settings > Extensions. -- That's server3

In Windows Admin Center, connect to the orchestrator server running Windows Server 2019 or Windows Server 2022.
This is the server that you'll install Storage Migration Service on and use to manage the migration. If you're migrating only one server, you can use the destination server as long as it's running Windows Server 2019 or Windows Server 2022. We recommend you use a separate orchestration server for any multi-server migrations. -- This is Server2

comments.content:
It was wrong.
Server2 and Server2.

discussion.content:
Yes, you can install Windows Admin Center on DCs, but Microsoft recommends not doing so for security (it increases the attack surface) and performance (it can consume a lot of resources and affect the performance of the DC).
Recommends installing Windows Admin Center on a dedicated administration server instead of a domain controller.

But in any case, we must forget about the WAC and Server3, which do not enter into the equation.

Storage Migration Service: Server2 (The destination where data from Server1 is to be moved)
Storage Migration Service extension: Server1 (the source server)
Server 1 and server 2 are server core, so only server 3 has desktop experience, wac must be installed on server 3

comments.content:
WAC installation is not supported on DCs

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/manage/windows-admin-center/plan/installation-options

discussion.content: The Storage Migration Extension is installed via WAC. Installing WAC on a domain controller is not supported. It has to be Server2 for both answers.

comments.content: I agree, you cannot install WAC on 2012, and DCs (NOT SUPPORTED as MS suggested). So both will be installed on Server 2.

Installing WAC on Server 2012 is not supported -> not on Server 1

discussion.content:
To migrate file shares from Server1 to Server2 using the Storage Migration Service, you should deploy the Storage Migration Service on the destination server, which is the newer version of Windows Server, as it will be orchestrating the migration process. The Storage Migration Service extension, on the other hand, should be installed on the source server from which the files are being migrated.

Therefore:

Storage Migration Service should be installed on Server2, which runs Windows Server 2022.
Storage Migration Service extension should be installed on Server1, which runs Windows Server 2012 R2.
Fill in the Answer Area as follows:

Storage Migration Service: Server2
Storage Migration Service extension: Server1
why do the extensions have to be installed in the DC? I think they should be installed in the Server 2 also.

Can anyone explain why Storage Migration Service is Server 2 and why Storage Migration Service extensio Server 3 ?
I don't understand.

From the link provided by shogoki69

An orchestrator server running Windows Server 2019 or Windows Server 2022 to manage the migration
If you're migrating only a few servers, and one of the servers is running Windows Server 2019 or Windows Server 2022, you can use that as the orchestrator. If you're migrating more servers, use a separate orchestrator server.
A PC or server running the latest Windows Admin Center to run the Storage Migration Service user interface, along with the latest Storage Migration Service tool (extension) available from the feed. The Windows Admin Center must be at least version 2103.

Answer is correct

Correct.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/storage-migration-service/overview#requirements

Selected Answer: B
As explain by NazerRazer and the guy below, disabling the FW is not a good idea and not a requirement for using Azure Migrate

comments.content:
No, disabling Windows Defender Firewall on Server1 alone does not fully meet the goal of ensuring that you can use Azure Migrate to migrate Server1.

Azure Migrate requires several prerequisites to be met for successful migration, including:

Mobility service installed: This requirement has already been met according to the provided information.
Network connectivity: NIC teaming is enabled on Server1, but this alone does not guarantee proper network connectivity for Azure Migrate. Ensure that network connectivity is properly configured to allow communication between Server1 and Azure services.
Firewall and security settings: While disabling Windows Defender Firewall may help resolve certain connectivity issues, it's not the only consideration. Azure Migrate requires specific ports to be open for communication. Disabling the firewall entirely may not be the best practice from a security standpoint.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
To ensure successful migration with Azure Migrate, you should:

Ensure that the necessary ports are open in the firewall for communication with Azure services.
Verify that NIC teaming is properly configured to maintain network connectivity during the migration process.
Ensure that Server1 meets the other prerequisites and recommendations provided by Azure Migrate documentation.
So, the correct answer is:
B. No

Option B. No

Disabling Windows Defender Firewall on Server1 is not a necessary step for Azure Migrate to function and does not address the requirements for migrating a server using Azure Migrate. The Azure Migrate appliance needs to communicate with Server1, but rather than disabling the firewall entirely, the appropriate ports should be allowed through the firewall. Disabling the firewall would unnecessarily expose Server1 to potential security risks. The Azure Migrate service requires certain ports and protocols to be open but does not require the firewall to be completely turned off.
So, the answer should be No.

I say the issue is the Mobility service being install.
"It is unsupported to install the Azure Migrate Appliance on a server that has the replication appliance or mobility service agent installed. Ensure that the appliance server has not been previously used to set up the replication appliance or has the mobility service agent installed on the server." https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/migrate/tutorial-discover-physical

discussion.content: this one is a nobrainer, the maximum forest functional level on Server 2012R2 is Server 2012R2, so the first thing you need to do is to move the roles to a different server, because during the upgrade, the domain roles might become unavailable

Make Sense!
Move FSMO to DC2
Upgrade DC1
Raise the domain and forest functional level.

The answers are correct, but it's tricky, microsoft not recomend you upgrade a dc in place.The correct way would be move the roles, depromotion the old dc and raise the funtional level

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/deploy/upgrade-domain-controllers

In the PowerShell window, use the Move-ADDirectoryServerOperationMasterRole cmdlet to move the FSMO roles.
Demote and remove the earlier Windows Server DC. (In this case upgrade would the option to select from given choices)
After the server is demoted and removed, you can raise the forest functional and domain functional levels to the latest version of Windows Server.

Answer is correct

It is not recommended but it is fully supported, and ADDS is upgradeable in-place.
